lines.text: Anything new on the Johnnie Peterson thing?
Who's Johnnie Peterson?
You mean you haven't heard?
No.

[Smiles]
The good American housewife loves her radio first and her husband second.

[Coyly, after Bill kisses her]
Bill, mother's in the house.
She is? Lucky for you.
She's gonna stay with me while you're gone.

[Holding her]
Good. Keep you out of trouble.
Susan, get a hold of yourself.
[Susan continues to read the newspaper article on the plane crash]
Susan, do you think yours is the only child born five years ago today?
He came from the shelter.
They handled hundreds of babies.
Oh, mother. All you have to do is look at him.
What do you expect me to see?
He has my mouth and my coloring.
Is that your evidence? A newspaper picture? Five years later?
I can't help it. I can feel it. It's mine.
All right. What if it is? There's nothing you can do about it except throw away your marriage. You think you can tell Bill?
I should have told him a long time ago the truth.
It's too late for the truth. Darling, listen to me.
If I hadn't listened to you, my child wouldn't have been on that plane.

I'm trying to help you. You made a mistake and have done your penance. Five minutes ago you told me you wrapped up your girlish grief. Don't bring it out in the open again. Don't do this to yourself. Don't do this to Bill.

[Before leaving for the military]
There's someone else.
Someone else?
Back home. Before I met you. I... I can't forget her. I tried to but I can't.
Do you really love her?

We went to school together. We've known each other since we were kids. Susan, I can't even explain it to myself. All I can ask is please forgive me... Say something. Say goodbye to me. Tell me you hope I get killed. But don't just stand there looking at me.
Why did you come here?
Just a reporter covering a story. Wouldn't it be ironic if it were my own?

[Handing her a gift]
For my prettiest reporter.
Orchids? Next time bring nylons.
I've met hundreds of guys coming back from overseas. You're just like they are. First thing they want is a companion and a chocolate soda.
What would I do with a chocolate soda?

[after Phyllis kisses him]
If that's your artillery, you just fired a blank.
Look, Phyl. I happen to be a sentimental guy that comes from a family of 12 kids. I get lonesome without eleven people around... or even one.

[after his matchsticks collapse at the bar]
The way they build things nowadays. No foundation. Just like people.
This will make you the biggest newpaperwoman since Nellie Bly.
Never heard of her.

[to Phyllis]
You had me fooled for a while. Long enough to get a license and marry you.
There's one legitimate thing about me. The way I love you.
Put it in your column.
Just for a moment there I thought you were a human being.

[after making a scene]
Well, what are you all staring at? Go back and write your headlines. That's what you're here for, isn't it? Let's see what kind of a story you can get out of a kid's body.
[She cries]
Ever since the beginning, you've been in and out of my life like a night visitor. This time don't bother to check in.
This time there happens to be a war. I didn't start it. I'm sorry there is one. But as long as there is, I'd be a chump if I didn't make it work for me.
I don't like war profiteers. You sell agony by the paragraph.
I'd like to speak my peace before I go.
Just so you keep it under a thousand words.

Only two words. I'm scared. I mean it, Duffy. Ever since I sold my first script for five dollars I've been fighting to get to the top. Stepped all over people. Been ruthless, conniving. Fought like a man in a man's world and I made it. But I don't want to lose you, Duffy. 'Cause this is home plate. If I lose you I'll roam around like a homeless alley cat with no place to come back to. Don't throw me out.
Why is it the only time you sound like a woman is in this crummy room?
'Cause it's ours, Duffy.
I shouldn't let you in.
You couldn't keep me out. It's always been that way, Duffy.
[They kiss]
I'm sorry for you, Phyl. You tried hard to be a woman. You just couldn't make it.
A good newspaper man leaves his emotions at home when he goes out on a job. You ought to know that.
All right, Hardin. I've done my best. Now you do your worst.
Who is the mother? Did you find out?
We cancelled the call.
But why?
We thought if was better if we never found out. In a way he belongs to all three of us. And since all of us can't have him, we decided that you are the one to try to adopt him.
I don't understand.
Yes, that was our decision.
But you just can't leave it like this. You aren't being fair to yourselves. You'll blame yourself all you life if you don't find out.
Listen, Susan. You can get Johnnie. No court in the world would turn you two down.
But if he's yours?
Even if he turned out to be mine I have nothing to offer him. Don't make me find him just to lose him all over again. It's much easier to tell myself that maybe he's yours.
Mr. Crossley's a genius. It says so in all the papers.
What do you know about being a genius?
His checks are good.
I'm telling you what's best for you. Go home. Forget him. Because he's forgotten you.
I'm not like the others. It's different this time.
Not for him it isn't.
I'm going to have his baby.
That IS different.
Thank you very much.

[Waking the hotel manager]
Where can I find Mrs. Chase?
Who?
Mrs. Chase. Isn't she registered?
Nobody's registered. I wouldn't know if Buffalo Bill and Annie Oakley were in the bridal suite.
Can you page her?
What?
I said can you page her?
You've got a loud enough voice. Why don't YOU page her?
